data.title: Accessibility: With NVDA, the second to last line of this text breaks.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:24:33.599Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
incremental-search|sie|0.2.1
code-spell-checker|str|1.4.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

0. turn on NVDA. 
1. Paste this into code, in a empty document. This code was taken from an NVDA pull request I'm working on.
    ```
    #IAccProcServer.py:
    #A part of NonVisual Desktop Access (NVDA)
    #Copyright (C) 2017 NV Access Limited, Derek Riemer
    #This file is covered by the GNU General Public License.
    #See the file COPYING for more details.
    
    """Implementation of IAccProcServer, so that customization of a wx control can be done very fast."""
    
    from logHandler import log
    from  comtypes.automation import VT_EMPTY
    from  comtypes import GUID, COMObject
    from comInterfaces.Accessibility import IAccPropServer
    
    #These are the GUIDS for IAccessible properties we can override.
    #Use these to look up the GUID needed when implementing a server.
    #These are taken from oleacc.h (oleacc.idl has them too).
    #Number of digits Format: "{8-4-4-4-12}"
    PROPID_ACC_NAME = GUID("{608d3df8-8128-4aa7-a428-f55e49267291}")
    PROPID_ACC_VALUE             = GUID("{123fe443-211a-4615-9527-c45a7e93717a}")
    PROPID_ACC_DESCRIPTION = GUID("{4d48dfe4-bd3f-491f-a648-492d6f20c588}")
    PROPID_ACC_ROLE = GUID("{CB905FF2-7BD1-4C05-B3C8-E6C241364D70}")
    ```
2. go to the     `PROPID_ACC_DESCRIPTION = GUID("{4d48dfe4-bd3f-491f-a648-492d6f20c588}")` line.
3. Now, go to the end of the line, and press backspace.

Expected: The last character is announced as it is deleted. 
Actual: Nothing speaks, but the character is deleted.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Intellisense with non static imports/require
data.body:
**Disclaimer**

1. I am not sure if this is the right repo to place this issue, so please guide me if not.
2. I searched stackoverflow and existing issues and found nothing for it.

I was trying to find a way to make `dynamic imports` or `non-static imports` to provide intellisense. For example

I have a file called `user.js` with following contents

```js
module.exports = function () {
  return {
    username: 'virk'
  }
}
```

And another file called `index.js` with following contents

```js
var userModule = './user'

const user = require(userModule)()
console.log(user)
```

When typing `user.` I get no intellisense, since the engine behind autocomplete may not have access to the `userModule` value and hence it fails.

## Hey that's not the right way?
Maybe you are right, but going there can be so many use cases where the require statements receives a dynamic value, which is part currently running application.

Also going forward, ES6 will have a [Loader](https://whatwg.github.io/loader/) API, where you can register modules or even can define a custom loader for a given application and I do think that intellisense will fail in that case too.

## No offense
The above points may have nothing to do with intellisense at all, since the design behind the entire system works on static analysis.

But the reason I created the issue, since I know that a `TSServer` runs inside a separate process to provide Typescript intellisense, which means there can be other ways too to use a loader which is part of a certain application.

Thanks 😄

data.title: Optional chaining suport in Javascript
Test: multi root workspace format changes when saving
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/33270, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/33328

- [x] Windows @jrieken
- [x] Linux/macOS @aeschli 

Complexity: 2

There are two cases where we write to the workspace configuration file: 
* you add or remove folders via the explorer context menu
* you save the workspace to another file (File > Save Workspace As...)

**Verify for both actions:**
* the workspace file is not turning into garbage and can be opened
* comments in the workspace file are preserved
* Windows: paths are saved with forward slash ("/") in case all the other paths in that file use slash, otherwise backslash is used in case any of the paths in the file already use backslash

data.title: Test: transition into multi-root workspace without window reload
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32945

- [x] Win @gregvanl
- [x] Mac @weinand 
- [x] Linux @isidorn 

Complexity: 4

We no longer require a window reload when entering a workspace. 

**Verify** for the following actions:
* Empty window: Add folders...
* Empty window: Save workspace as...
* 1-folder window: Add folders...
* 1-folder window: Save workspace as...
* Workspace window: Save workspace as...

**That**:
* our UI updates accordingly (e.g. explorer, window title)
* our migration of UI state (local storage) and hot-exit backups works properly
  * no data-loss: your dirty files are kept and restored when you now do a restart and new dirty files that you create after the transition are also restored properly
  * your UI state is kept and restored when you now restart the instance
* any window-workspace settings are migrated over to the workspace file (only when transitioning from a 1-folder window)
* extensions work properly still (we do restart the extension host!)

Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4891

- [x] anyOS - @alexandrudima 
- [x] anyOS - @seanmcbreen 

Complexity: 2

The `files.encoding` setting can now be configured per file type. Verify:
* this works as advertised
* this also works for untitled files when switching the language mode

**Note:** switching the language mode of a saved file (not untitled file) will not change the encoding of the file because that would basically need to trigger a load again of the file and this should be under user control.

Also, the icon does not appear in the "program toggle bar" (alt + tab) making it impossible to re-open a minimized project.

![vscode no icon](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11805103/30705867-f68e1294-9ef6-11e7-91df-d3cfe3250d47.png)

Sorry if there are other issues covering this. I tried to search, but there are so many issues, so might have missed it.

data.title: Test: Improved --wait behaviour
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24327

- [x] Win - @auchenberg 
- [x] Mac - @sandy081 
- [x] Linux - @aeschli  

Complexity: 2

Running code with `--wait` parameter from the command line makes the command line process wait until the window that opens is closed. During this milestone we are now tracking the file to open as argument and also terminate the calling process when all the files are closed. This allows to reuse an existing Code instance for this purpose.

* verify you can use `--wait` with 0, 1 or many files and the calling process terminates when the files close
* verify the command line will terminate also when the target window closes or when the target window gets another folder opened

data.title: Test: improved editor history navigation
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29027

- [x] macOS - @weinand 
- [x] anyOS - @aeschli 

Complexity: 2

The editor history navigation tracks movements across editors as well as movements within an editor (cursor selection changes). The actions Go > Back and Go > Forward can be used to navigate within the history.

During this sprint the history was changed:
* you need at least 10 lines difference to the last cursor location to add a new history stop
* moving the cursor less than 10 lines will always update the last history stop of the file to that location to prevent adding unwanted stops

Play around with the history navigation and see if you find some counterintuitive behaviour. Also use programmatic selection changes like "Goto Definition".

**Note:** history currently does not track navigation across editor groups, there is an issue open for that.

data.title: Link scrolling in editor split-view
data.body:
Feature request:

Allow scrollbars of editors in split-view to be linked such that, for example, if you scroll the left editor, the right editor scrolls with it at the same time. This makes comparing two files more easy.

data.title: Syntax highlighting for YAML documents breaks with certain single quotes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

Check out the syntax highlighting on this file:

```yaml
- hosts: localhost
    - name: Create EMR cluster
      command: >
        aws emr create-cluster \
            --name "{{cluster_name}}" \
            --release-label "emr-{{emr_version}}" \
            --applications "Name=Hadoop" "Name=Spark" "Name=Zeppelin" \
            --no-auto-terminate \
            --auto-scaling-role "EMR_AutoScaling_DefaultRole" \
            --use-default-roles \
            --log-uri {{log_uri}} \
            --ec2-attributes '{
                "KeyName": "{{key_name}}",
                "SubnetId": "{{subnet_id}}",
                "AdditionalMasterSecurityGroups": {{additional_security_groups | to_json}},
                "AdditionalSlaveSecurityGroups": {{additional_security_groups | to_json}}
            }' \
            --instance-groups file://files/instance-group-config.json \
            --scale-down-behavior TERMINATE_AT_TASK_COMPLETION \
            --bootstrap-action "Path={{bootstrap_uri}}" \
            --tags {{emr_tags}}
      register: create_cluster
    #
    # Coloring works fine here on GitHub.
    #
    - set_fact:
        cluster_id: "{{(create_cluster.stdout | from_json).ClusterId}}"
```

Looks fine here, but on VS Code it's broken:

![screen shot 2017-09-21 at 11 32 49 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1039369/30704399-a2482386-9ec0-11e7-9190-67c7ff2c4a21.png)

It appears that the single quotes from L12-L17 break syntax highlighting for everything afterwards.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Test: macOS touchbar
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14653

- [x] macOS  - @alexandrudima 
- [x] macOS  - @auchenberg 

Complexity: 3

We enabled support to show commands (with either icon or label) in the macOS touch bar. The commands are context aware and registered per window (switching windows will update the touch bar).

**Built-in**
* verify out of the box you get touch bar entries that you can use
* verify the debug touch bar behaves properly depending on your debug state (running, not running, stopped) and all commands work

**Extensions**
Extensions can add new commands via the menu API by registering to the `touchBar` location:

```json
"contributes": {
	"menus": {
		"touchBar": [
			{
				"command": "markdown.showPreview",
				"when": "editorLangId == markdown",
				"group": "navigation"
			}
		]
	}
}
```

Verify you can register commands to the touch bar and then `when` condition is respected. The touch bar will always take the context of the active editor to resolve the commands. The resource of the active editor will be passed to the command you register as context. 

**Note:** your command can either have a label or icon. If you chose an icon, make sure to use PNG, as SVG is currently not supported.

data.title: Delete matching parentheses, brackets, or braces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.3.9600
- Extensions: Extensions are disabled
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file.
2. Paste the following code: `var foo = (1 + bar) + baz;`.
3. Position the cursor before the first `(`. It and its matching parenthesis should highlight.
4. Hit the delete key.
5. Only the first parenthesis is deleted.

It would be useful if the corresponding parenthesis, brace, or bracket were deleted when the targeted one was.

I see two ways to accomplish this:
1. Add a shortcut for both backspace and delete that does the operation on the matching character.
2. Automatically do the deletion. This could be an extension of the already-existing "editor.autoClosingBrackets" setting or (more likely) a new setting that governs this behavior.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Test: link origin of messages in debug console
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24490

- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 
- [x] OS X - @octref 
- [x] Linux - @chrmarti 

Complexity: 3

We now support showing the origin of messages in debug console. Note that this is currently only supported by the `node2` debug adapter. Have some nedo repository, for example our smoketest and if you have node below version 8 add `"inspector": "protocol"` to the launch configuration.

Verify: 
* all output logged should appear in the debug console with a proper origin.
* clicking on the origin takes you to the appropriate file / line number / column

When using `console.log`, `console.warn` or `console.error` from an extension, the log information is serialised from the extension host to the renderer and then played back in the renderers DevTools console as well as debug console. This means that the origin of the console use from the extension is lost. We now preserve the origin and allow access to it.

Use `console.log`, `console.warn` or `console.error` from your extension with strings, objects, primitives etc. Have some extension repository and verify:
* you can expand the message in the extension host dev tools to see the full stack of where the message was sent
* you see the location of the message in the right hand side of the debug console and can click on it
* the data that you log is not shown up in a bad way or is lost

data.title: Disable peek editor and just open the file directly when there are multiple definitions
data.body:
I'ld like to know if there is a way to:

When I press `F12` (Go to Definition) just open the file **without** the "peek editor" opened.

I mean, the current behavior is that when you press F12: 
* **First**: the related file is opened
* **Second**: you're faced with the "Peed editor"  

![screen shot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/376842/28370365-05244f72-6c92-11e7-8ed6-f9247f153911.png)
* **Third**: I usually press `ESC' to close it and stay in the file

I don't want to need to press that `ESC`. There is a way to configure it?

Related [question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41460845/disable-peek-in-visual-studio-code) on SO with 11 upvotes and no answer.

data.title: feature request - filter folders in explorer view
data.body:
In every project in node, you have hundreds of folders under node_modules.

Next to the "Explorer" name at the top of the opened project (or project name or open editors) i would create a filter input text field.
What the filter tag would do, if you enter more than 3 character, it would filter all the directory and files according to their names, and show only the filtered ones with the related folder structures.

In the existing search panel it would be good, if the folder structure would remain, not just showing files purely.

It would be very efficient, at the moment, i'm looking ionic-angular folder on my workspace, and it's the 100th folder under node_modules. It's very cumbersome and hard to scroll. (as to drag the scroll, you need to be very-very precise, the scroll steps is too thin on hundreds of folders)

Extension manager filter is a good example for it.
